title: Macroglossum bombylans
text:
Macroglossum bombylans, the humble hummingbird hawkmoth, is a <a href="moth">moth</a> of the family <a href="Sphingidae">Sphingidae</a>. It is known from <a href="Nepal">Nepal</a> through <a href="China">China</a> to <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>, <a href="Korea">Korea</a> and <a href="Japan">Japan</a>, with one record from the <a href="Russian%20Far%20East">Russian Far East</a>. It is also found in northern <a href="Thailand">Thailand</a>, northern <a href="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> and the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a>.
The <a href="wingspan">wingspan</a> is 40–52 mm. In northern China there are two generations per year, with adults on wing from May to August. In Korea, adults have been recorded from mid-July to mid-October. Adults have been found feeding at flowers of "<a href="Barleria%20cristata">Barleria cristata</a>" and "<a href="Duranta%20erecta">Duranta erecta</a>" in Hong Kong, usually at dawn and late in the afternoon. Adults are also a minor fruit-piercing pest of "<a href="Citrus%20junos">Citrus junos</a>" in South Korea.
Larvae have been recorded feeding on "<a href="Rubia%20cordifolia">Rubia cordifolia</a>" in India, "<a href="Rubia%20akane">Rubia akane</a>" in Japan and "<a href="Paederia">Paederia</a>" and "<a href="Stauntonia">Stauntonia</a>" species elsewhere.
